sub_topic: Finding the velocity and acceleration of an object using calculus
message_1: A car is traveling along a straight road given by the equation s(t) = 2t^3 - 3t^2 + 6t, where s is the position of the car in meters and t is the time in seconds. Find the velocity and acceleration of the car at t=2 seconds.
message_2:
To find the velocity of the car, we need to find the first derivative of the position function s(t) with respect to time t. This will give us the velocity function v(t):

v(t) = ds/dt = d(2t^3 - 3t^2 + 6t)/dt

Using the power rule for differentiation, we get:

v(t) = 6t^2 - 6t + 6

Now, we need to find the velocity at t = 2 seconds. Plug t = 2 into the velocity function:

v(2) = 6(2)^2 - 6(2) + 6
v(2) = 6(4) - 12 + 6
v(2) = 24 - 12 + 6
v(2) = 18

So, the velocity of the car at t = 2 seconds is 18 meters per second.

Next, we need to find the acceleration of the car. To do this, we find the second derivative of the position function s(t) with respect to time t, which is the first derivative of the velocity function v(t):

a(t) = dv/dt = d(6t^2 - 6t + 6)/dt

Using the power rule for differentiation, we get:

a(t) = 12t - 6

Now, we need to find the acceleration at t = 2 seconds. Plug t = 2 into the acceleration function:

a(2) = 12(2) - 6
a(2) = 24 - 6
a(2) = 18

So, the acceleration of the car at t = 2 seconds is 18 meters per second squared.

In conclusion, at t = 2 seconds, the car has a velocity of 18 meters per second and an acceleration of 18 meters per second squared.
